children.name: invalid
children.definition: a ticket, passport etc that is invalid cannot legally be used and it will not be officially accepted: không hợp lệ
examples: I’m afraid your ticket is invalid on this route.
This passport is invalid. Look at the expiry date.

children.name: out of date
children.definition: /ˌaʊt əv ˈdeɪt/  a ticket, passport etc that is out of date cannot be used because the time during which it could be used has passed: hết hạn
examples: ▪ Are you aware that your passport is out of date?

children.name: days/months/years out of date hết hạn vài ngày, vài tháng, vài năm
examples: ▪ He tried to get on the train using a pass that was months out of date.

children.name: null and void
children.definition: /ˌnʌl ən ˈvɔɪd/  a document such as a contract that is null and void has no legal force and cannot be used for any purpose - used in legal contexts: không hiệu lực
examples: ▪ If the contract has not been signed by witnesses, it is considered null and void.

children.name: info that is kept to be used later
record
children.definition: information about something that is written down or stored on computer, film etc so that it can be looked at in the future: hồ sơ

children.name: the records show sth
examples: Official records show that 44 businesses have stopped trading in the last 12 months.

children.name: keep a record
examples: Teachers keep a record of students’ progress.

children.name: maintain a recordformal
examples: The directors are responsible for maintaining adequate accounting records.

children.name: place/put something on record
children.definition: officially say something or write it down
examples: I wish to put on record my objection to the scheme.

children.name: access records
children.definition: alsohave/gain access to records
examples: (= be able to look at them )Every citizen has the right to access their medical records.

children.name: a written record
examples: Where written records do survive, they are incomplete.

children.name: historical records
examples: Using historical records, we have produced an image of the temple.

children.name: official records
examples: This has been the wettest winter since official records began.

children.name: an accurate record
examples: Many hospitals did not keep accurate records.

children.name: a detailed record
examples: Edwardian travellers left detailed records of their journeys.

children.name: a proper record
examples: Failure to maintain proper records would be a criminal offence.

children.name: confidential records
examples: They were transferring confidential student records onto computer.

children.name: a permanent record
examples: You will have a permanent record of your work.

children.name: medical/hospital/health etc records
examples: The hospital could not find my mother’s medical records.|Patients’ hospital records are kept on a database.

children.name: financial records
examples: The company’s financial records must be up-to-date.

children.name: public records
children.definition: records of births, deaths etc, that the public are allowed to look at
examples: He found the information while examining public records.

children.name: police records
examples: Violent assaults rose 39 percent, according to police records.

children.name: the biggest/highest etc on record
examples: Last summer was one of the hottest on record.

children.name: a matter of public recordformal
children.definition: something that has been written down so that anyone can know it
examples: His salary is a matter of public record.

children.name: record of
examples: I try to keep a record of everything I spend.
According to official records, five people were killed last year near that road junction.

children.name: archives
children.definition: a collection of records that provide information about the history of a country, organization, family etc:tài liệu lưu trữ
examples: New evidence has come to light from the 40-year-old United Nations archives.
The Public Record Office is a central repository for all government archives.

children.name: register
children.definition: an official list of names kept for legal purposes that records information such as who attends a particular school, who has been born or has died, or who is legally allowed to do something:sổ, sổ sách
examples: Have you signed thehotel register?
Police want anational registerof DNA samples.
Teachers were reminded that school attendance registers were actually legal documents.

children.name: electoral registera list of the names and addresses of all the people who are old enough to votedanh sách bầu cử
examples: Why are there 1 million people missing from the electoral register?

children.name: register of
examples: To find out about her family history, she looked through the register of births, marriages, and deaths.

children.name: the official register of births, deaths, and marriages
log
children.definition: an official written record of something, especially a journey in a ship or plane: sổ lộ trình
examples: He complained to a senior officer, who made a note in the ship’s log.

children.name: log of
examples: Alice had to write up a detailed log of the trip, complete with scientific data.

children.name: chronicle
children.definition: a historical record in which events are recorded in the order in which they happened: biên niên sử
examples: Chronicles written by Roman scholars can give us a good idea of how their political system worked.

children.name: chronicle of
examples: The report is a chronicle of the history of the Party since its formation.

children.name: a chronicle of his life during the war years
certificate
children.definition: an official document that states that a fact or facts are true : giấy chứng nhận
examples: birth/death/marriage certificate(= giving details of someone’s birth, death, or marriage )

children.name: a medical certificate
examples: You can get a medical certificate that shows which vaccinations you've had.

children.name: a birth certificate
examples: In order to get a passport, you'll need your birth certificate.

children.name: a marriage certificate
examples: He found a copy of his parents' marriage certificate.

children.name: a death certificate
examples: According to his death certificate, he died aged 44.

children.name: a share certificate
children.definition: proving what shares someone owns
examples: She kept official letters and share certificates in a locked case.

children.name: issue a certificate
children.definition: officially provide one
examples: The certificate will be issued upon payment of the fee.

children.name: identification
children.definition: (abbID) official papers or cards, such as your passport , that prove who you are : giấy tờ tùy thân
examples: Have you got any ID? A driving licence or cheque card will do.
We were asked to show some identification before the security guards would let us in.
Do you have any identification?
form/proof of identification
Bring some form of identification, preferably a passport.
fingerprinting as ameans of identification
photo ID/ identification(an identity document that includes a photograph of the holder)

children.name: ID card
children.definition: / identity cardB1 a card with your name, date of birth, and photograph on it, that proves who you are : thẻ căn cước

children.name: licence
children.definition: UK/licenseUS  an official document giving you permission to own or do sth for a period of time →permit:
examples: The dealers applied for an export licence.

children.name: have a licence
examples: Café Metropole does not yet have a license to sell liquor.

children.name: hold a licenceBritish English
children.definition: have a licence
examples: Police said that the man did not hold a firearms licence.

children.name: get/gain/obtain a licence
examples: New private pilots must fly for at least fifty hours before getting their licences.

children.name: apply for a licence
examples: A doctor who moves to another state must apply for a license to practice medicine there.

children.name: grant/issue a licence
examples: He was granted his flying instructor’s licence.

children.name: renew a licence
examples: The licence must be renewed yearly.

children.name: lose your licence
examples: The police caught him driving while drunk and he will now lose his licence.

children.name: a licence runs out
children.definition: alsoa licence expiresformal
examples: (= it ends )Her driver’s license had expired.

children.name: take away sb’s licence
children.definition: alsorevoke somebody's licenceformal
examples: The doctor had his license revoked after he was found to be on drugs.

children.name: a driving licence
examples: British English,a driver's licenseAmerican English 80 percent of 18 year olds had a driver’s license.

children.name: a pilot’s licence
examples: She became the youngest woman to hold a pilot’s licence.

children.name: a television licenceBritish English
children.definition: which allows you to use your television and pays for public television programmes
examples: Buying a television means you will need a television licence.

children.name: a marriage licence
children.definition: a licence that allows two people to marry each other
examples: We went to get a marriage licence.

children.name: a fishing/hunting licence
children.definition: a licence that allows you to fish/hunt
examples: He renewed his hunting license.

children.name: an import/export licence
examples: An export licence was issued in August last year.

children.name: a provisional licenceBritish English
children.definition: a temporary driving licence before you get your full licence
examples: Learner drivers need to obtain a provisional licence.

children.name: a full licence
children.definition: one that is not temporary and has no restrictions
examples: They offer insurance cover for drivers over 25 and under 70 years of age with a full licence.

children.name: the licence holderBritish English
children.definition: the person who has a licence
examples: the licence holder of a public house

children.name: a licence fee
children.definition: money you have to pay to get a licence
examples: The BBC is funded by a licence fee which all television owners have to pay.

children.name: passport
children.definition: a small official document that you get from your government, that proves who you are, and which you need in order to leave your country and enter other countries : hộ chiếu
examples: I have an Irish passport.
They need to check that your passport is in order.
a passport photograph/photo
a passport applicationthe processing of passport applications

children.name: have/hold a passport
examples: I have a Canadian passport.

children.name: apply for a passport
examples: You can apply for an Italian passport if your parents are Italian.

children.name: get a passport
children.definition: alsoobtain a passportformal
examples: It took quite a long time to get a new passport.

children.name: renew a passport
examples: I'd forgotten to renew my passport.

children.name: travel on a passport
examples: The men were convicted of travelling on a false passport.

children.name: a
examples: British/American etc passportShe was born in India but has a British passport.

children.name: a valid passport
children.definition: one that is officially acceptable
examples: For travel abroad, you must have a valid passport.

children.name: a false/forged passport
children.definition: alsoa fake passportinformal
examples: He used a false passport to enter Kenya.

children.name: a passport holder
children.definition: someone who has a passport
examples: British passport holders must obtain a visa before entering the country.

children.name: permit
children.definition: an official document that allows you to do something or go somewhere : giấy phép
examples: She has managed to obtain a temporary residence permit.

children.name: have a permit
examples: Do you have a resident's parking permit?

children.name: need/require a permit
examples: EU citizens no longer need a permit to work in the UK.

children.name: get a permit
examples: You have to get a special permit in order to visit the Saiq plateau.

children.name: issue a permit
examples: Up to ten fishing permits are issued each day.

children.name: obtain a permit
children.definition: more formal than 'get'
examples: Hunters are required to obtain a permit.

children.name: apply for a permit
examples: Farmers must apply for permits to use the new chemicals.

children.name: a work permit
examples: She had problems getting a work permit for the States.

children.name: a parking permit
examples: You’ll need to apply for a residential parking permit.

children.name: a travel permit
examples: Palestinians have to obtain a travel permit for travel between the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.

children.name: a residence permit
children.definition: alsoresidency permitespecially American English
examples: (= one that allows you to live in a country )Residence permits will be limited to five years.

children.name: an export permit
examples: An export permit is required for the export of this timber.

children.name: a gun permit
examples: More than 300,000 civilians, in a country of 6 million, have gun permits.

children.name: a fishing permit
examples: To fish you’ll need a rod licence and a fishing permit.

children.name: permit for
examples: A permit is required for fishing in the canal.

children.name: permit to do sth
examples: Do you need a permittowork here?

children.name: document
children.definition: a paper or set of papers with written or printed information, especially of an official type : văn kiện, tài liệu

children.name: official/confidential/legaldocuments
examples: They are charged with usingforgeddocuments.
Several secret documents went missing from the government’s Infomation department.
Your birth certificate is an important document, which should be kept safe at all times.

children.name: visa
children.definition: an official mark put on your passport that gives you permission to temporarily enter or leave a foreign country :
examples: I was still in New York, trying to get a visa to visit Russia.

children.name: apply for a visa
examples: I applied for a visa to visit China.

children.name: get a visa
children.definition: alsoobtain a visaformal
examples: He was having difficulties getting a visa.

children.name: give sb a visa
children.definition: alsogrant somebody a visaformal
examples: She has been granted a special visa.

children.name: refuse/deny somebody a visa
examples: The Lebanese embassy refused him a visa.

children.name: somebody's visa expires/runs out
children.definition: it ends
examples: I had 14 days to leave the country because my visa had expired.

children.name: extend/renew somebody's visa
children.definition: allow a visa to apply to a longer time
examples: He hoped that his visa might be extended.

children.name: overstay your visa
children.definition: stay longer than you are allowed to
examples: Two women in the group had overstayed their visas.

children.name: a tourist/travel/visitor's visa
examples: He applied for a tourist visa.

children.name: a work/student visa
examples: They'd sent their daughter abroad on a student visa.

children.name: an entry/exit visa
examples: All foreigners need an entry visa.

children.name: a transit visa
children.definition: a visa that allows you to pass through a particular country
examples: Transit visas will be issued at the airport.

children.name: a 14-day/six-month etc visa
examples: Special 10-day visas were issued to cover the time of the conference.

children.name: a visa application
examples: U.S. immigration authorities have turned down their visa application.

children.name: the visa requirements
examples: Check the visa requirements with your travel agent.

children.name: on a ... visa
examples: We travelled to Argentinaona tourist visa.

children.name: valid
children.definition: /ˈvælɪd, ˈvæləd/  if a ticket, passport etc is valid, you can legally use it and it will be officially accepted.: có hiệu lực
examples: ▪ Do you have a valid driver’s license?
valid for có hiệu lực cho
▪ Your ticket is valid for travel at any time of the day.
valid for 10 years/two months/one week etc có hiệu lực 10 năm, 2 tháng, 1 tuần
▪ My passport is valid for 10 years.
valid/ˈvæl.ɪd/adjective có giá trị; có hiệu lực; hợp lệ
A ticket or other document is valid if it is based on or used according to a set of official
conditions which often include a time limit
_My passport is valid for another two years.

children.name: current
children.definition: a current official document has not yet reached the date after which it can no longer be used: hiện hành
examples: Acceptable forms of ID include a current passport or a birth certificate.

children.name: small details in aset of rules or contract
small print
children.definition: especially UK/fine printUS all the rules and details relating to a contract or agreement : phần chữ in nhỏ

children.name: the small print/ fine print
examples: A close study of the small print will reveal that many of these insurance policies do not cover the cost of repairing storm damage.

children.name: read/check the small print
examples: Always read the small print before you sign anything.
I’m afraid you can’t cancel your contract now. You should have read the small print.

children.name: technicality
children.definition: a small detail in a set of rules or a law, especially one on which a decision is based: các chi tiết nhỏ
examples: The vote was declared invalid because of a technicality.
The case against him had to be dropped because of a legal technicality.

children.name: on a technicalitybecause of a technicality
examples: Baxter was released on a technicality because his ‘offence’ was committed in the city, and only a city judge had the authority to sign the warrant.
The proposal was rejected on a technicality(= because of a technicality ).

children.name: part of a law or legal agreement
article
children.definition: /ˈɑːʳtɪkəl/  one of the parts, usuallynumbered, of awrittenlaw or legal agreement:

children.name: điều lệ
examples: ▪ Article 1 of the constitution guarantees freedom of religion.
▪ The country signed the treaty but then violated each of its 143 articles.

children.name: clause
children.definition: /klɔːz/  a part of awrittenlaw or legal document, concerning a particular point or idea:

children.name: điều khoản
examples: ▪ I was told that this clause would be removed from the contract.
▪ Courts ruled that prayer in school violates a clause of the First Amendment.

children.name: renewable
children.definition: if an agreement or official document is renewable, you can make it continue for a further period of time after it endsOPP non-renewable: có thể gia hạn
examples: It’s a six-month lease but it’s renewable.
a renewable visa
a renewable passport/contract

children.name: non-renewable
children.definition: if an official document or agreement is non-renewable, its use cannot be continued for an extra period of time after it has ended: không thể gia hạn
examples: Foreign workers bringing dependents could obtain only one non-renewable two-year visa.

children.name: contract
children.definition: nounhợp đồng; giao kèo; khế ước
examples: a legal document that states and explains a formal agreement between two different people or groups, or the agreement itself
_a contract of employment
_a temporary/building contract
_They could take legal action against you if youbreak (the terms of)the contract.
_My solicitor isdrawing up(= writing) a contract.
_Don'tsign/enter intoany contract before examining its conditions carefully.
_[ + to infinitive ]They're the firm of architects whowonthe contracttodesign theNationalMuseumextension.

children.name: constitution
children.definition: nounLAWShiến pháp

children.name: (a written document which forms) the set of political principles by which a state or organization is governed, especially in relation to the rights of the people it governs
examples: _Britain has nowrittenconstitution.

children.name: _The ConstitutionoftheUnited States
examples: _Under(= As part of) the union constitution, a new committee must be elected each year.
